Accommodation
The first challenge you will face is to find a new home. This may be in public (social) housing or in private\
column3: rented housing.

column2: Tell me about social housing
Tell me about private housing
What if I am homeless?
Can I get financial assistance for rent?
What do I need to do before I start renting?
Back to the main menu
In Ireland\
column3: city and county councils (also known as local authorities) provide social housing for people who cannot afford housing from their own resources. You should call into your local authority office and ask their help and advice about finding somewhere to live.

column2: Housing associations and housing co-operatives also provide social housing for people who cannot afford to buy their own homes or rent a home in the private sector. You can find a list of housing associations at www.citizensinformation.ie (click on ‚ÄòHousing‚Äô).
Not everyone has a right to local authority housing. It depends on your eligibility and needs
column3: including household income limits. There is also a long waiting list. The rent is decided based on the income (after tax) of all people over 18 living in the home. You must fill out an application form for local authority housing. Your local authority or local Citizens Information Centre can help you with this.

column2: Housing associations and housing co-operatives also have rules about who may be eligible for their housing. Again\
column3: your local Citizens Information Centre can help with this.

column2: What points do I need to watch for when applying for social housing support?
You can only apply to one housing authority.
In general
column3: you must already be living in the area covered by that housing authority or have a local connection with the area through previous residence\
column4: current employment\
column6: education or relatives ‚Äì though a housing authority may agree to waive (ignore) this requirement.

column2: You must send a completed application form to the relevant local authority. You can get the forms from the authority
When completing the application form\
column3: you can choose up to three areas (‚ÄúAreas of Choice‚Äù) within the local authority area you want to live. However\
column4: if applying to an authority in Dublin\
column6: you can choose three areas in that county\
column7: one of which must be in the area of the authority you are applying to.

column2: Your application will be assessed by the local authority based on eligibility criteria
column3: including income\
column4: right of residency and the availability of alternative accommodation.

column2: Once you satisfy the eligibility criteria\
column3: your housing need will be assessed. This assessment takes account of your current accommodation

column2: If your local authority decides that you meet both the eligibility and need criteria you will be placed on a waiting list (now known as a ‚Äòrecord of qualified households‚Äô). Each local authority decides on its own rules for deciding order of priority on the waiting list (an ‚ÄúAllocation Scheme‚Äù). You can get a copy of this scheme from your local authority.
While you have some choice in specifying the areas where you would like to live
column3: you should remember that if you choose a popular area
column4: you may wait longer for an offer of housing than if you choose a less popular area. The demand for social housing is high and you can expect to wait a number of years before a local authority can offer you a house (depending on your housing needs and availability of suitable accommodation)

column2: If you do not qualify for social housing or will have to wait a long time for social housing\
column3: you should look at renting in the private sector.

column2: The Private Residential Tenancies Board (PRTB) oversees the private rental sector in Ireland. Its website\
column3: www.prtb.ie\
column4: explains the rights and responsibilities of tenants (you) and landlords. The website also has a Good Tenant Guide which you can download.

column2: You can also get information and advice from Threshold\
column3: the national housing charity. See www.threshold.ie

column2: The cost of renting varies greatly. Expect to pay a lot more if you choose to live in\
column3: or near\
column4: a city. You can find details of typical rents in different parts of Ireland on www.prtb.ie

column2: You will usually have to pay a deposit and the first month‚Äôs rent before you can move into rented housing.
Both Threshold and Focus Ireland\
column3: charities that help people at risk of homelessness\
column4: may be able to help you find housing that accepts the rent supplement payment or Housing Assistance Payment (HAP)

column2: What documents might the landlord ask for?

üíÅ character references from people who know you well
üíº professional references\
column3: usually from your employer and

If you or someone you know is homeless or at risk of becoming homeless\
column3: you can get information and advice from:

column2: üè† the housing section of your local authority
‚òé the Dublin City Council 24-hour Homeless Helpline at 1800 707 707 or the Homeless Persons Unit at 1800 724 724 ‚Äì if you live in Dublin
‚òé the Cork City Council‚Äôs Homeless Persons Unit at (021) 480 5495 ‚Äì if you live in Cork;
üè• the Community Welfare Officer in your local health office
‚Ñπ your local Citizens Information centre
‚òé the Private Residential Tenancies Board (PRTB) (phone: 0818 30 30 37) ‚Äì if you are in private rented accommodation and need advice and information on your rights as a tenant; and
üíª www.threshold.ie ‚Äì will provide additional information on your rights as a tenant
There are two types of financial support with rent payments:
Housing Assistance Payments (HAP) provided by some ‚Äì but not all ‚Äì local authorities; and
Rent Supplement payments provided by the Department of Social Protection
Housing Assistance Payment
Rent Supplement

HAP is a new form of housing support provided by some local authorities where you find your own place to live. HAP is being introduced on a phased basis. Ask your Local Authority about HAP support in your area.
HAP will mean that some local authorities can now provide housing assistance for households who qualify for social housing support. Under HAP
column3: local authorities will make the full rent payment ‚Äì on behalf of the HAP recipient ‚Äì directly to the landlord. The HAP recipient will then pay a rent contribution to the local authority. The rent contribution is based on income and the ability to pay.

column2: Under HAP\
column3: you are allowed to take up full-time employment without losing your HAP payment. The tenancy agreement will be between you and your landlord. (The local authority is not your landlord.)

column2: You must pay the deposit yourself. In some cases you may be eligible for an ‚Äòexceptional needs‚Äô payment from the Department of Social Protection to help with paying the deposit
If you live in a county where HAP is not yet available\
column3: you can apply to the Department of Social Protection for the Rent Supplement payment. This will pay some of the cost of the rent.

column2: üí∂ Rent Supplement is paid to people living in private rented housing who cannot pay the full rent themselves. To qualify for the Rent Supplement payment:
üìÉ you must be on the social housing waiting list
ü™ôyour income must be below a certain level (if your only income is a social welfare payment\
column3: you will probably qualify); and

column2: ‚úî you may have to meet other conditions.
You can find out more from your local Department of Social Protection office\
column3: from www.welfare.ie or from your local Citizens Information Centre.

column2: Decide on the area you would like to live in and contact that local authority to get a housing application form ‚úÖ
Complete and return the form to the housing section of the local authority. If you qualify for social housing\
column3: you will be placed on the housing waiting list ‚úÖ

column2: Ask the local authority how long you may be waiting for a house ‚úÖ

Start looking for private rented housing. Ask your local authority if the Housing Assistance Payment (HAP) is available in your area. (You will find more information on HAP in the section on Help with paying your rent.) ‚úÖ
If HAP is not yet available in your area\
column3: contact your local Department of Social Protection office and ask how to apply for the rent supplement payment. You will find a list of Department of Social Protection offices on www.welfare.ie ‚úÖ

column2: If you need help with paying the deposit and first month‚Äôs rent\
column3: ask the Department of Social Protection if you can apply for an ‚Äòexceptional needs payment‚Äô to help with this cost. ‚úÖ

column2: When you find accommodation\
column3: contact the Department of Social Protection to see if you qualify for the rent supplement payment. ‚úÖ

column2: Agree a rent amount with your landlord and find out what is included in the rent (for example\
column3: gas\
column4: electricity\

column2: Make sure you get a lease or tenancy agreement from your landlord. This is an important document. If you don‚Äôt understand it\
column3: ask someone to help you (for example\
column4: Threshold) ‚úÖ

column2: Check to see if the gas\
column3: electricity\
column4: water and other services will be put in your name and if you will have to pay these bills. Most likely this will be the case. If necessary\
column5: pay a transfer or connection fee ‚úÖ

column2: Do not pay your deposit until you have looked at the property and are satisfied with it ‚úÖ
Broaden your search to find accommodation at a price you can afford ‚Äì if you need to ‚úÖ
Education
In Ireland\
column3: by law\
column4: children must be educated from the ages of 6 to 16 (or until they have completed three years of second-level education). Children\
column7: refugees or children of migrant workers\
column8: have the same right to education as other children in Ireland. The Irish education system is made up of primary\

column2: Tell me about early childhood education
Tell me about primary education
Tell me about second-level education
Tell me about third-level education
Tell me about further education
Early childhood education in Ireland is not part of the formal education system. It is run by a wide range of private\
column3: community\
column4: and voluntary groups. These include cr√®ches\

column2: The ECCE programme (Free Pre-school Year in Early Childhood Care and Education) is designed to give children (usually under 4 years of age) access to a free pre-school year of appropriate programme-based activities in the year before they start primary school. More information can be found on www.dcya.gov.ie.
Children attend primary school between the ages of 4 and 12. Primary schools are also known as National Schools. There are several types:
denominational (religious) schools;
multi-denominational schools;
non-denominational schools;
Irish-speaking schools (called Gaelscoileanna);
schools for children with special educational needs arising from a disability; and
private primary schools.
Education in State primary schools is free. However\
column3: you must pay if you want your child to be educated in a private primary school. The school year is from September to June.

column2: Primary schools are overseen by Boards of Management.
Children begin their second-level education around the age of 12 and leave around the age of 17 or 18.
The second-level school cycle is five years with two State examinations during that time\
column3: the Junior Certificate after three years and the Leaving Certificate after five years. Some schools also offer a ‚Äòtransition year‚Äô after the Junior Certificate\
column4: making the school cycle six years in total.

column2: The earliest a child can leave school is 16 years (or after they have completed three years of second-level education\
column3: whichever is later).

column2: Is there English language support for students?
Young children learn English very quickly. Even if your child has very little English
column3: they will normally be placed in a class with children of the same age. At both primary and second-level there is additional language support for children who do not speak English as their first language.

column2: Is there special needs support for students?
Children with special educational needs arising from a disability get extra support either in their own school or in special schools. More information can be found on www.ncse.ie.
Third-level education is also known as higher education. It includes courses run by universities\
column3: institutes of technology\
column4: colleges of education\

column2: Access to higher education for students moving on from second-level education is based on the Leaving Certificate\
column3: which is the final state examination at the end of second-level school.

column2: The Central Applications Office (CAO) manages applications to higher education institutions. You can apply for a place by sending a completed application form to the CAO. You can get more information on www.cao.ie.
Is there financial support to attend third level?
Financial help for students is means-tested (it is based on the family income). Grants are available to help meet living expenses\
column3: transport costs\
column4: and/or college fees. The grants are managed by Student Universal Support Ireland (SUSI). You can find out more on their website\

column2: Some students may be able to get additional help. They include: students with disabilities who are attending full time Third Level and Post-Leaving Certificate (PLC) courses; and students who may not be able to continue their third-level studies for financial reasons.

This help is provided by the National Access Office of the Higher Education Authority (HEA). You can get more information about this at www.hea.ie. Students can also ask their college or university for more details
Is there any help for refugees or asylum-seekers?
Yes\
column3: there is some. Since 28 August 2015\
column4: a new pilot (trial) scheme was set up for students leaving secondary school. The new scheme is targeted at school leavers who are in the protection system (other than at deportation order stage)
column7: to student support in line with the current Student Grant Scheme. Students have to meet the following criteria:

column2: ‚úÖ Meet the definition of a protection applicant or a person at leave to remain stage (other than those at deportation order stage)
‚úÖ Have passed their leaving certificate;
‚úÖ Have been accepted on an approved Post Leaving Certificate course or an approved undergraduate course
‚úÖ Have attended at least five academic years in the Irish school system\
column3: as at 31 August 2015; and

column2: ‚úÖ Have been part of an application for protection or at leave to remain stage (other than deportation order stage) for a combined period of at least 5 years as at 31 August 2015.
More information on the above scheme can be found on www.education.ie
Are my educational qualifications recognised in Ireland?

It depends. Quality and Qualifications Ireland (QQI) is the state agency responsible for providing advice on the recognition of foreign qualifications in Ireland and the recognition of Irish qualifications abroad. You can get more information on their website www.qqi.ie.
Further education is education and training which takes place after second-level school but which is not part of the third-level system. It includes programmes such as:
Post-Leaving Certificate (PLC) courses
Vocational Training Opportunities Scheme (VTOS) ‚Äì this is second-chance education for unemployed people
Youthreach programmes for early school-leavers;
literacy and basic education programmes;
evening classes for adults in second-level schools.
You can get more information on www.education.ie (click on Further Education and Training) or from your local Education and Training Board.
Further information about the Irish education system\
column3: including supports available\
column4: can be found on the Department of Education and Skills website\

column2: Healthcare
In Ireland\
column3: the public health service is run by the Health Service Executive (HSE). The HSE oversees public hospitals. It also operates a network of local health offices and health centres which provide a range of health and social services.

column2: HSE Local Health Offices
Registering with a family doctor (GP)
Public Health Nurse
Medical emergencies
Other healthcare services
Your local health office is your entry point to community health and personal social services. Local health offices and health centres provide a wide range of services including:

üë®‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è Public Health Nursing

üë™ Community Welfare

üëÅ Ophthalmic (care of the eye)
üó£ Speech Therapy
üë™ Social Work
üíä Addiction Counselling and Treatment
üèã Physiotherapy
‚ôø Occupational Therapy
üß† Psychiatric services
To access health services\
column3: you will need to register with a family doctor in your area. You will have to give your name\
column4: address\
column5: contact number and date of birth to the doctor. You will find a list of General Practitioners on www.icgp.ie

column2: If you change your doctor and you already hold a medical card or GP visit card
column3: you must ask your local health office for a new medical card or GP visit card.

column2: Some GPs only offer services to private patients\
column3: while others may deal with both private and medical/GP card patients. Your local Health Office can provide you with details of the GPs in your area who accept medical/GP card patients.

column2: In Ireland\
column3: if your family income is below a certain level\
column4: you may be entitled to a Medical Card. This card entitles you and your family to free healthcare from a GP (family doctor)\
column6: free care in public hospital emergency departments\
column7: and a range of other free healthcare services.

column2: If your family income is above this level\
column3: you may be entitled to a GP Visit Card. This card gives you free visits to your family doctor but you must pay for medicines and other healthcare services.

column2: Children under the age of 6 years and people over the age of 70 years are automatically entitled to a GP Visit Card.
If you do not qualify for either of these cards\
column3: you must pay for GP visits\
column4: medicines and other primary healthcare services.

column2: If you are changing doctor\
column3: you should tell your current doctor of your plans to change and ask that your medical history be sent on to your new doctor. If you qualify for a medical card\
column4: you may need to check if the new doctor is accepting new patients.

column2: Do I have to pay to go to the hospital?
For acute public hospital services\
column3: including emergency department services\
column4: you do not have to pay\
column5: but you will normally need a letter from your GP (a referral letter) to access public hospital services.

column2: If you do not have a referral letter from your GP\
column3: or a medical card\
column4: you will be charged ‚Ç¨100 for accident and emergency services.

column2: Hospital services are also available from a number of private hospitals. You will have to pay the full cost for private hospital services unless you have private health insurance which covers the cost.
You can get more information on public health services and how to apply for a medical card or GP visit card from your local health office.
Public health nurses provide a range of services free of charge in your community.
If you have been registered with a public health nurse during your stay in State Accommodation\
column3: it is important to give the public health nurse your new address when you leave. This allows the nurse to follow up with you\
column4: or refer you to the local public health nurse near your new residence.

column2: For more information on Public health nurses\
column3: please visit www.hse.ie

column2: In a medical emergency\
column3: you should phone 112 or 999 and tell the operator about the emergency

column2: Additional information on other healthcare services and service providers can be found on www.hse.ie\
column3: or by contacting your local health office
